cell.html: A former High Guard officer accidentally "frozen" in time for over 300 years during which time the Systems Commonwealth was all but destroyed. Upon his resurgence from the Event horizon of the black hole, he became devoted to the restoration of the Systems Commonwealth at all costs.
cell.text: A former High Guard officer accidentally "frozen" in time for over 300 years during which time the Systems Commonwealth was all but destroyed. Upon his resurgence from the Event horizon of the black hole, he became devoted to the restoration of the Systems Commonwealth at all costs.

cell.html: Captain of the Eureka Maru and First Officer on Andromeda
cell.text: Captain of the Eureka Maru and First Officer on Andromeda

cell.html: A headstrong, no-nonsense cargo ship captain (and smuggler), very protective of her crew and with little respect for rules and formal regulations.
cell.text: A headstrong, no-nonsense cargo ship captain (and smuggler), very protective of her crew and with little respect for rules and formal regulations.

cell.html: A Nietzschean of the exterminated Kodiak Pride; a former mercenary. Selfish and smart, he always plots his actions carefully, and the only person he is completely loyal to is himself.
cell.text: A Nietzschean of the exterminated Kodiak Pride; a former mercenary. Selfish and smart, he always plots his actions carefully, and the only person he is completely loyal to is himself.

cell.html: Another Nietzschean, a genetic reincarnation of Gaheris Rhade (Dylan's old First Officer, who had betrayed him at the Battle of Hephaistos).
cell.text: Another Nietzschean, a genetic reincarnation of Gaheris Rhade (Dylan's old First Officer, who had betrayed him at the Battle of Hephaistos).

cell.html: A genius engineer, good-natured but often egocentric and childish. Grew up on Earth, and hates most Nietzscheans and Magog with passion.
cell.text: A genius engineer, good-natured but often egocentric and childish. Grew up on Earth, and hates most Nietzscheans and Magog with passion.

cell.html: An avatar of the sun. She is apparently immortal, has the power to create and destroy and can foresee all possible futures at once. She looks young and naive in season 1, but changed significantly in mid-season two and season five. She tends to change the subject when asked about her origin or her native tongue/name.
cell.text: An avatar of the sun. She is apparently immortal, has the power to create and destroy and can foresee all possible futures at once. She looks young and naive in season 1, but changed significantly in mid-season two and season five. She tends to change the subject when asked about her origin or her native tongue/name.

cell.html: An unusually intelligent Magog who has accepted Wayism religion. A complete pacifist, rejecting any violence and hating himself because of his race. Often serves as a counsellor for other crew members. His birth name translates from Magog as "Red Plague".
cell.text: An unusually intelligent Magog who has accepted Wayism religion. A complete pacifist, rejecting any violence and hating himself because of his race. Often serves as a counsellor for other crew members. His birth name translates from Magog as "Red Plague".

cell.html: An artificial intelligence which controls the ship (and numerous robots and androids) and can replace most of the functions of crew. Can appear as a human-like woman on any display or as a hologram. The display and the hologram possess quite different aspects of the AI personallity.
cell.text: An artificial intelligence which controls the ship (and numerous robots and androids) and can replace most of the functions of crew. Can appear as a human-like woman on any display or as a hologram. The display and the hologram possess quite different aspects of the AI personallity.

cell.html: An autonomous android physically indistinguishable from a human. Her personality is separate from the Andromeda and Rommie is more emotional and even capable of love as a result.
cell.text: An autonomous android physically indistinguishable from a human. Her personality is separate from the Andromeda and Rommie is more emotional and even capable of love as a result.

cell.html: An android built by Harper when Rommie was destroyed. Even more "human" than Rommie; was initially programmed to think she is human. Harper used some of Rommie's remains to create Doyle.
cell.text: An android built by Harper when Rommie was destroyed. Even more "human" than Rommie; was initially programmed to think she is human. Harper used some of Rommie's remains to create Doyle.

context.text: Andromeda (TV series) - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Character Actor Position on the Andromeda Description
[ edit ] Recurring and notable guest characters

When Engels took over and the show began the more "episodic" format, reactions from fans were mixed. The new producers tried to lighten the "doom and gloom" seriousness of the original story arc, while at the same time focusing more on the Dylan Hunt character. As a result, many felt that the quality of the series had declined.
The events of the episode "Ouroboros", the final episode written by Wolfe, introduced the last major changes that Wolfe was willing to make to the series.

In discussion on his web site's forums and various interviews over the last two years, Wolfe has elaborated that he was released from the production staff after he refused to shift the show's focus more heavily onto Kevin Sorbo 's character, Dylan Hunt, by essentially making all of the show's episodes Hunt-centric.

Controversy erupted during the midst of the second season when series developer and executive producer Robert Hewitt Wolfe announced he had been released from the show's production, though his influence was felt through the completion of the second season; at that point, Bob Engels was brought on to executive produce the series. The reason for the change was purportedly to make the show more episodic and open to "casual viewing," as Wolfe's version although episodic had many continuing plotlines and story arcs. After the show's final episode aired, Wolfe wrote and published on his site a one-act play titled "Coda" that explained his intended plans for the show without contradicting the already aired episodes.
[ edit ] Controversy over Robert Hewitt Wolfe's departure

Slipstream is the primary mode of travel for ships in the Andromeda universe, and the only known method of travelling faster than the speed of light . The Vedran discovery of the Slipstream was instrumental in the formation of their interstellar empire, which became the precursor of the Systems Commonwealth .
The Abyss is finally destroyed, and Dylan's battle is over. The Route of Ages transforms into a slipstream portal, allowing the Commonwealth fleet to return to Tarn-Vedra.
